Description: ASSISTANCE WITH BLM ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND PALEONTOLOGICAL CURATION AND NAGPRA REPATRIATION

INCREASING PRESSURE AND DEMANDS ON PUBLIC LANDS AND RESOURCES IN ALASKA COUPLED WITH THE EXPANSIVE NATURE OF PUBLICLY OWNED RESOURCES (235 MILLION ACRES OF FEDERAL AND 100 MILLION ACRES OF STATE LAND) CREATED THE NEED FOR A CENTRAL LIBRARY AND INFORMATION SERVICE. THE ALASKA RESOURCES LIBRARY AND INFORMATION SERVICES (ARLIS) HAS CONSOLIDATED A NUMBER OF EXISTING FEDERAL, STATE, AND UNIVERSITY LIBRARIES TO FORM A VASTLY MORE COMPREHENSIVE SOURCE OF INFORMATION ON ALASKAS NATURAL RESOURCES IN A SINGLE LOCATION, SERVED BY A HIGHLY QUALIFIED STAFF.ARLIS IS NEEDED IN THE STATE OF ALASKA TO MEET THE DEMAND FOR A CENTRAL LIBRARY AND INFORMATION SERVICE DEDICATED TO RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF UAA AND BLM ARE PART OF THE STATEMENT OF WORK TO BE COMPLETED OVER THE COURSE OF THE AGREEMENT. ARLIS IS A COST-EFFECTIVE SOLUTION TO THE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT INFORMATION SERVICE ISSUE, AS IT IS A COOPERATIVE EFFORT OF FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES POOLING THEIR RESOURCES AND WORKING TOGETHER. ARLIS IS A CRUCIAL SOURCE OF ALASKA RESOURCE MANAGEMENT INFORMATION FOR THE PUBLIC, PRIVATE AND UNIVERSITY SECTORS.UAA AND BLM, BOTH ARLIS FOUNDING AGENCIES, SHARE THE OBJECTIVE OF PROVIDING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT INFORMATION RESOURCES AND SERVICES TO ARLIS-AFFILIATED AGENCIES AND THE PUBLIC IN A COST-EFFICIENT MANNER. UAA PROVIDES PUBLIC ACCESS TO ARLISS COLLECTIONS DURING MORE THAN 100 OPEN HOURS EACH WEEK, AS WELL AS FACILITATING THE ARLIS UAA CONSORTIUM LIBRARY JOINT ELECTRONIC CATALOG THAT PROVIDES ACCESS TO A SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF ELECTRONIC RESOURCES 24 HOURS A DAY.ARLIS REMAINS LOCATED IN 20,000 SQ. FT. OF UAAS CONSORTIUM LIBRARY BUILDING AND SERVES AS A REPOSITORY FOR INFORMATION AND RESEARCH ON THE CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES OF ALASKA. UAA PROVIDED THE SPACE, HIRES STAFFING AS SUPPORTED BY THE ARLIS BUDGET AND PERFORMS MANAGEMENT AND PROCUREMENT AS NECESSARY FOR ARLIS OPERATIONS.THIS PROJECT IS A CONTINUATION OF HOUSING AND PROVIDING ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT FOR ARLIS, TO ADDRESS PUBLIC, PRIVATE AND UNIVERSITY SECTOR NEEDS FOR INFORMATION RESOURCES AND SERVICES PERTAINING TO ALASKAS NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES. ARLIS DIRECTOR BRANDY WATTS IS PI FOR THE PROJECT. UAA STAFF MEMBERS WORK INCLUDES PROCESSING AND CATALOGING LIBRARY MATERIALS, PROVIDING REFERENCE SERVICES, CIRCULATION OF MATERIALS, PROCESSING AND FULFILLING INTERLIBRARY LOANS, AND MANAGING THE ARLIS NETWORK.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00170FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:  THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS CLEARLY DEFINED IN THE PROPOSAL TO AID THE BLM IN UNDERSTANDING THE IMPORTANT HISTORY OF THE PUBLIC LANDS RESOURCES AT THE DOUGLAS POINT SPECIAL RECREATION AREA AND ALLOW FOR INTERPRETATION OF THOSE HISTORIC RESOURCES. FURTHER THE WORK WILL SUPPORT THE PROTECTION OF KNOWN ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCES ASSOCIATED THE CHILES HOMESITE AND INVESTIGATE THE POTENTIAL FOR AS YET UNKNOWN RESOURCES TO BE LOCATED OUTSIDE OF PROTECTED AREAS. THE TECHNICAL APPROACH CLEARLY IDENTIFIES THE METHODS TO ACHIEVE THE OBJECTIVES AND PRESENT A SERIES OF IMPLEMENTABLE PROJECTS SCHEDULED OUT OVER THE COURSE OF THE AGREEMENT. THE SUCCESS OF EACH OF THESE PROJECTS PROVIDES A MEANINGFUL APPROACH TO MEASURE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE WORK. THE PROPOSAL PROVIDES DETAILS OF THE TECHNICAL APPROACH AND OUTCOMES FOR EACH OF THE PROJECTS AND IDENTIFIES THE ROLES THE APPLICANT HAS IN ACHIEVING THEM. THE PROPOSAL INCLUDES A CLEAR SCHEDULE OF MILESTONES TASKS FOR THE DURATION OF THE AGREEMENT. GOALS   ESTIMATED TIMELINES: A.DETERMINE IF THE PREVIOUS GEOPHYSICAL STUDY OF THE AREA NEAR THE CHILES FAMILY CEMETERY IS INDEED A SERIES OF UNMARKED GRAVES OF THE ENSLAVED.  B.LOCATE THE FORMER QUARTER SITE AND STRUCTURES WHERE THE ENSLAVED WOULD HAVE LIVED AND WORKED, AND  C.IDENTIFY AS MANY POTENTIAL OUTBUILDINGS IN ORDER TO UNDERSTAND THE SPACES THOSE RESIDING ON THE PROPERTY WOULD HAVE MOVED THROUGH IN THEIR EVERYDAY LIVES

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00170FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:  THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS CLEARLY DEFINED IN THE PROPOSAL TO AID THE BLM AND OTHER PARTNERS IN THE MANAGEMENT OF JUPITER INLET LIGHTHOUSE OUTSTANDING NATURAL AREA (ONA) TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, AND ENHANCE THE UNIQUE AND NATIONALLY IMPORTANT HISTORICAL, NATURAL, CULTURAL, SCIENTIFIC, EDUCATIONAL, SCENIC, AND RECREATIONAL VALUES OF THE SITE AS STATED IN THE CONGRESSIONAL DESIGNATING LEGISLATION (PUBLIC LAW 110-229 SEC. 202. MAY 8, 2008). THE PROPOSAL FURTHER OUTLINES THE CROSS OVER BETWEEN THE ORGANIZATIONS MISSION AND THE BLMS MANAGEMENT AT THE ONA. THE PROPOSAL IS RELEVANT AS IT AIDS IN ACHIEVING THE DIRECTION SET BY CONGRESS IN THE ONAS DESIGNATION, MEETS WITH BLMS MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES AND PLANNING FOR THE SITE AND ALIGNS WITH DOI PRIORITIES RELATING TO EXPANDING ACCESS, RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND THE STEWARDSHIP OF PUBLIC LANDS RESOURCES. THE WORK IS REALISTIC BASED ON THE PAST EXPERIENCE OF 8 YEARS OF PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE PROPONENT AND THE BLM AND IS MEASURABLE BASED ON THE ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF THE SPECIFIC PROJECTS WITHIN THE PROPOSAL AND THE OVERALL CONTRIBUTIONS TO MANAGEMENT OF THE ONA E.G., EDUCATIONAL ENHANCEMENT, VISITOR SATISFACTION, SCIENTIFIC EXPLORATION ETC.  THE TECHNICAL APPROACH CLEARLY IDENTIFIES THE METHODS TO ACHIEVE THE OBJECTIVES AND PRESENT A SERIES OF IMPLEMENTABLE PROJECTS SCHEDULED OUT OVER THE COURSE OF THE AGREEMENT. THE SUCCESS OF EACH OF THESE PROJECTS PROVIDES A MEANINGFUL APPROACH TO MEASURE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE WORK. THE PROPOSAL PROVIDES DETAILS OF THE TECHNICAL APPROACH AND OUTCOMES FOR EACH OF THE PROJECTS AND IDENTIFIES THE ROLES THE APPLICANT HAS IN ACHIEVING THEM. THE PROPOSAL INCLUDES A CLEAR SCHEDULE OF MILESTONES TASKS FOR THE DURATION OF THE AGREEMENT.  THE PROJECT PROPONENT, FLORIDA PUBLIC ARCHAEOLOGY NETWORK, MISSION IS TO PROMOTE AND FACILITATE THE CONSERVATION, STUDY AND PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF FLORIDA S ARCHAEOLOGICAL HERITAGE. THE JUPITER INLET LIGHTHOUSE OUTSTANDING NATURAL AREA SERVES AS ONE OF FPANS KEY SITES IN SOUTH FLORIDA ATLANTIC REGION TO ACHIEVE THEIR MISSION. THE PROPOSALS OBJECTS IS AS FOLLOWS: OBJECTIVE 1: PROMOTE AWARENESS OF FLORIDAS UNIQUE ARCHAEOLOGICAL HERITAGE THROUGH EDUCATION. OBJECTIVE 2: AID IN EDUCATION AND INTERPRETATION OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCES, THE SCIENCE OF ARCHAEOLOGY, AND THE PROFESSIONS INSTRUMENTAL TO THE FURTHERANCE OF CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. OBJECTIVE 3: COLLABORATIVE DEVELOPMENT OF PROGRAMS AT THE JUPITER INLET LIGHTHOUSE OUTSTANDING NATURAL AREA, INTERPRETIVE MATERIALS, EDUCATIONAL  CONTENT AIMED  AT  ENHANCING  AWARENESS  AND  UNDERSTANDING  OF  THE  IMPORTANCE  OF  CULTURAL RESOURCE  MANAGEMENT, INSTILLING  A  STEWARDSHIP  ETHIC  FOR  THE  ONAS  UNIQUE  AND SIGNIFICANT  RESOURCES  ALONG  WITH A  WIDER  RESPECT  FOR  CULTURAL RESOURCES  ACROSS  THE NATION, AND THE PROFESSIONS KEY TO THEIR PROTECTION, PRESERVATION AND INTERPRETATION. MEASURES: THE PROJECTS CLEARLY IDENTIFIED IMPLEMENTATION ACTIONS ESTABLISH A NUMBER OF SPECIFIC EXPECTED OUTCOMES ALONG WITH THE GENERAL OUTCOMES ASSOCIATED WITH PROTECTING, PRESERVING AND ENHANCING THE CORE VALUES AND KEY RESOURCE OF THE ONA INLINE THE CONGRESSIONAL DESIGNATION.

THIS PROJECT REQUIRES A CREW WHO CAN DO HANDS-ON WORK ON PASSIVE RESTORATION TECHNIQUES. WITH MINIMAL TRAINING AND EQUIPMENT, A SMALL CREW CAN COMPLETE THESE TASKS WITH MINIMAL SUPERVISION. THE NORTHERN ARAPAHO ON PREVIOUS CONSULTATIONS WITHIN THE PFO HAVE EXPRESSED DIFFERENT INTERESTS IN COORDINATING ON ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECTS.THIS OPPORTUNITY IS TO WORK WITH THE NORTHERN ARAPAHO TRIBE TO ASSIST BLM WITH INSTALLING BEAVER DAM ANALOGS (BDAS) AND ZEEDYK ROCK STRUCTURES AND REPAIRING EXISTING EXCLOSURE FENCES TO PREVENT FURTHER EROSION AND PROMOTE WETLAND WET MEADOW RECOVERY ALONG TRIBUTARIES OF PINE GROVE AND FOGARTY CREEKS IN THEHEADWATERS OF DRY PINEY CREEK, AND WET MEADOWS IN THE HEADWATERS OF BIRCH CREEK.

THE TRIBE S MISSION AND OBJECTIVE IS TO FULFILL THE TRIBE S OBLIGATIONS REFLECTED IN THE INTER-GOVERNMENTAL COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT AND SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT AND DELIVERY OFRECOMMENDATIONS AND GUIDANCE FROM THE TRIBE TO INFORM AND BE INCORPORATED INTO THE BUREAU OFLAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  AND THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE FOREST SERVICE S  FORESTSERVICE , PREPARATION OF THE BEARS EARS NATIONAL MONUMENT  BENM  MANAGEMENT PLAN, TRAVELMANAGEMENT PLAN, INDIVIDUAL PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WITHIN THE MONUMENT, AND ONGOINGMANAGEMENT OF BENM. SPECIFICALLY, THE TRIBE S OBJECTIVES ARE TO   ENHANCE THE ABILITY OF THE MEMBERS OF THE TRIBE TO COMMUNICATE THEIR IMPORTANTKNOWLEDGE, LOCAL EXPERTISE, AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE OVERALL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE BEARSEARS REGION BEYOND THE PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT AS WELL AS THE CULTURAL IMPORTANCE ANDTRADITIONAL USE OF THE AREA THROUGH RECOMMENDATIONS AND GUIDANCE ON THE BENMMANAGEMENT PLAN, WORK WITH THE FEDERAL AGENCIES ON FUTURE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PLAN,ONGOING PROJECTS, AND THE MANAGEMENT DIRECTION OF THE MONUMENT. THE TRIBE POSSESSESHIGHLY SPECIALIZED AND UNIQUE TRADITIONAL AND HISTORIC KNOWLEDGE THAT IS CRITICAL TO THESUCCESSFUL MANAGEMENT OF BENM.  FACILITATE THE ATTENDANCE BY OFFICIAL REPRESENTATIVES OF THE TRIBE AT REGULAR MEETINGS WITHTHE FEDERAL AGENCIES, SUCH AS ANNUAL MEETINGS TO DEVELOP JOINT ANNUAL WORK PLANS WITH THEFEDERAL AGENCIES AND QUARTERLY MEETINGS TO, AMONG OTHER THINGS, ENGAGE IN A JOINT DIALOGAND KNOWLEDGE SHARING OF THE TRIBE S AND FEDERAL AGENCIES  LAND MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES,THE TRIBAL CONTEXT OF THE LANDSCAPE, MONUMENT OBJECTS AND OTHER PUBLIC LANDS, NATURALAND CULTURAL RESOURCE ISSUES.  COLLABORATE WITH THE OTHER COALITION TRIBES AND THE FEDERAL AGENCIES TO ENHANCE THEPUBLIC S UNDERSTANDING OF THE TRIBE S PARTICULAR CONNECTIONS TO THE BEARS EARS LANDSCAPE,CULTURAL RESOURCES AND NATURAL RESOURCES THEREIN, AND THE TRIBE S IMPORTANT ROLE IN THESTEWARDSHIP OF THE BENM, INCLUDING OPPORTUNITIES TO ENGAGE TRIBAL YOUTH.  COLLABORATE WITH THE OTHER COALITION TRIBES AND THE FEDERAL AGENCIES TO ENHANCE THEPUBLIC S RESPECT AND TREATMENT OF THE BEARS EARS. THE TRIBE VIEWS THE GREATER BEARS EARSLANDSCAPE AS A PART OF THE PERSONAL IDENTITY OF ITS MEMBERS AND AS A CULTURAL LIVINGSPACE A LANDSCAPE WHERE THEIR TRADITIONS ARE EMBEDDED, WHERE THEIR ANCESTORS ENGAGEDIN AND HANDED DOWN CULTURAL PRACTICES, AND WHERE THEY DEVELOPED AND REFINED METHODS OFCARING FOR THE LAND. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THE FEDERAL AGENCIES  MANAGEMENT OF BENMBETTER REFLECT THE TRIBE S IRREPLACEABLE CONNECTION TO THE BEARS EARS LANDSCAPE.  SUPPORT ONGOING ASSISTANCE FROM THE TRIBE TO COLLABORATE ON THE MANAGEMENT OF BENM,INCLUDING OBTAINING INPUT FROM TRIBAL MEMBERS - IN PARTICULAR TRIBAL ELDERS - W HO CANNOTTRAVEL TO REMOTE SITES, WHICH WILL IMPROVE OVERALL MANAGEMENT OF PUBLIC LANDS, NATURALRESOURCES, AND CULTURAL RESOURCES DUE TO THE TRIBAL NATIONS  UNIQUE AND HISTORICALCONNECTION AND UNDERSTANDING OF BENM.

THE INSTITUTE FOR HERITAGE EDUCATION  IHE  IS A 501 C  3  NONPROFIT PARTNER OF PROJECT ARCHAEOLOGY  PA   IHE HAS SUPPORTED PA IN SEVERAL WAYS SINCE BECOMING ACTIVE IN CULTURAL HERITAGE EDUCATION IN LATE 2019, INCLUDING THROUGH A CURRENT COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM , COLORADO STATE OFFICE  THE MAIN WAY WE DO SO NOW IS TO TAKE ON THE ADMINISTRATIVE AND FUNDRAISING SIDE OF THE WORK SO THAT THE PROFESSIONAL EDUCATORS TRAINED IN PA MATERIALS AND METHODS CAN SPEND THEIR TIME EXPANDING THE EDUCATION REACH OF THE PROGRAM THE PROPOSED AWARD WILL BE USED TO HOST ONE PROJECT ARCHAEOLOGY WORKSHOP FOR TEACHERS IN ELKO USING THE PA CURRICULUM INVESTIGATING SHELTER  THIS WORKSHOP, USING AN INVESTIGATION APPROACH, ENABLES TEACHERS TO USE THE MATERIALS SUCCESSFULLY IN THE CLASSROOM, AND TO REACH THEIR STUDENTS IN AN ENGAGING WAY  ALL PA MATERIALS EMPHASIZE THE NEED FOR STEWARDSHIP AND PROTECTION OF CULTURAL RESOURCES ON PUBLIC LANDS, MATCHING A BLM CULTURAL RESOURCE OBJECTIVE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS IS AN OPTIMAL AVENUE TO BENEFIT YOUNG STUDENTS AND NEVADA S CULTURAL RESOURCES  RESEARCH SHOWS THAT ONE OF THE MOST EFFECTIVE WAYS TO PROTECT CULTURAL RESOURCES IS TO PROVIDE CLASSROOM TEACHERS AND INFORMAL EDUCATORS WITH HIGH QUALITY MATERIALS TO EDUCATE AND INSPIRE STUDENTS TO TAKE PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THESE RESOURCES  ADDITIONALLY, THE MATERIALS PROVIDE HIGH QUALITY INVESTIGATIONS OF PAST CULTURES AND CONTEMPORARY DESCENDANT COMMUNITIES, THEREBY INCREASING EDUCATIONAL EQUITY OF DIVERSE AND UNDERSERVED AMERICANS THIS PROJECT WILL MEET BLM S GOALS BY PROTECTING CULTURAL RESOURCES ON PUBLIC LANDS THROUGH EDUCATION  THE MOST SIGNIFICANT AND LASTING IMPACT OF PROJECT ARCHAEOLOGY IS ITS UNIQUE ABILITY TO FOSTER CULTURAL UNDERSTANDING, PROMOTE SCIENTIFIC AND HISTORICAL INQUIRY, ENCOURAGE ETHICAL REASONING AND CITIZENSHIP, AND ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF THE LEGAL BASIS AND SOCIETAL NEED FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION  INTERDISCIPLINARY IN NATURE, ARCHAEOLOGY OFFERS AN EXCELLENT VEHICLE FOR SEAMLESSLY INTEGRATING SCIENCE, HISTORY, GEOGRAPHY, ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTS, AND VISUAL ARTS  THE EXISTING PA MATERIALS AND THE NEW SUPPLEMENTAL CURRICULUM WILL PROVIDE ENGAGING INQUIRY BASED MATERIALS FOR STUDENTS FOR YEARS TO COME

THIS AGREEMENT IS TO   SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT AND DELIVERY OF RECOMMENDATIONS AND GUIDANCE FROM THE   ZUNI TRIBE  THE TRIBE  TO INFORM AND BE INCORPORATED INTO THE BLM S AND THE   UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE FOREST SERVICE S  THE FEDERAL   AGENCIES  PREPARATION OF THE BENM MANAGEMENT PLAN, INDIVIDUAL PROJECTS AND   PROGRAMS WITHIN AND ONGOING MANAGEMENT OF BENM THE TRIBE WILL SUPPORT THE   IMPLEMENTATION OF THE OBJECTIVES, GOALS, AND VALUES OF THE TRIBAL LAND   MANAGEMENT PLAN INTO THE FINAL BENM MANAGEMENT PLAN, AND TO SATISFY THE   TRIBE S OBLIGATIONS OUTLINED IN THE INTERAGENCY COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT  THE   EXPECTED DELIVERABLE IS A BENM MANAGEMENT PLAN THAT REFLECTS THE TRIBE S   VALUES AND RELATIONSHIP TO THE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES IN THE   MONUMENT

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO DEVELOP   AND DELIVER RECOMMENDATIONS AND GUIDANCE TO INFORM FEDERAL AGENCIES REGARDING THE   UTE INDIAN TRIBE S CULTURAL VALUES AND   KNOWLEDGE OF THE   BEARS EARS NATIONAL MONUMENT  BENM  SO THEY CAN BE INCORPORATED INTO THE BENM   MANAGEMENT PLAN, INDIVIDUAL PROJECTS, PROGRAMS WITHIN THE BENM, AND ONGOING   MANAGEMENT OF THE BENM  A SECONDARY   OBJECTIVE IS ESTABLISHING THE TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE INSTITUTE   TKI   FOR   EDUCATING PEOPLE, INDIANS AND NON INDIANS ALIKE, ABOUT THE BENM AND ITS   NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES AS A PART OF THIS AGREEMENT THE TRIBE WILL   ENSURE THAT ITS OBJECTIVES, GOALS, AND VALUES FOR LAND MANAGEMENT ARE   INCORPORATED INTO THE   FINAL BENM MANAGEMENT PLAN AND TO SATISFY THE   TRIBE S OBLIGATIONS OUTLINED IN THE INTER  GOVERNMENTAL COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT   FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF THE BENM  IN THE FUTURE THIS WORK MAY INCLUDE ENGAGING   ELDERS, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND YOUTH

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO ENHANCE THE ABILITY OF THE MEMBERS OF THE HOPI TRIBE, IN PARTICULAR TRIBAL ELDERS AND TRIBAL YOUTH, TO COMMUNICATE THEIR ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE, EXPERTISE AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE SPIRITUAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE BEARS EARS REGION AND PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT  THE HOPI TRIBE POSSESSES HIGHLY SPECIALIZED AND UNIQUE TRADITIONAL AND HISTORICAL KNOWLEDGE THAT IS CRITICAL TO THE SUCCESSFUL MANAGEMENT OF BEARS EARS NATIONAL MONUMENT  BENM   INFORMATION WILL FOCUS ON THE AREA S CULTURAL IMPORTANCE AND TRADITIONAL USE THROUGH THE RECOMMENDATIONS AND GUIDANCE ON THE BENM MANAGEMENT PLAN, THE HOPI TRIBE WILL WORK WITH THE FEDERAL AGENCIES, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  AND UNITED STATES FOREST SERVICE  USFS , ON FUTURE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PLAN, ONGOING PROJECTS AND THE MANAGEMENT DIRECTION OF THE MONUMENT

THE OFFICE OF ARCHAEOLOGY AND HISTORIC PRESERVATION  OAHP  SERVES TO CARRY OUT THE DUTIES ASSIGNED TO COLORADO STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE  SHPO , WHICH COMPRISE DUTIES DIRECTLY RELATING TO HISTORIC PRESERVATION, INCLUDING THE PROTECTION AND PRESERVATION OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES UNDER THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT  NHPA  OVER THE FIVE YEAR AGREEMENT PERIOD, THE PARTIALLY SUPPORTED POSITION WILL BE TASKED WITH DIGITIZING, PROCESSING, AND ENTERING DATA FOR APPROXIMATELY 5,000 TOTAL SITE FORMS DOCUMENTS INTO THE OAHP RELATIONAL AND GEOSPATIAL DATABASES AND APPROXIMATELY 7,500 TOTAL SITES SURVEYS AS PENDING INTO THE OAHP GEOSPATIAL DATABASE  THIS POSITION WILL ALSO PROVIDE BLM STAFF AND CONTRACTORS SITE AND DOCUMENT NUMBERS UPON REQUEST THROUGHOUT THE LENGTH OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT THE INFORMATION ENTERED INTO THE AUTOMATED DATABASE, COMPRISING CULTURAL AND PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES ON COLORADO S PUBLIC LANDS, BENEFITS AND IS ACCESSIBLE TO PROFESSIONAL RESEARCHERS, EDUCATORS, AND THE PUBLIC, AS WELL AS SERVING AS A RESOURCE FOR SHPO STAFF, CONTRACTORS, RESEARCHERS, FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL, AND TRIBAL DIVISIONS NEEDING LEGITIMATE ACCESS TO THIS INFORMATION FOR THE PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT OF HISTORIC AND NATURAL RESOURCES  BY FURTHER ENGAGING THE PUBLIC AND SERVING AS A RESOURCE TO THOSE WHO ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING THESE RESOURCES, IT IS THE ULTIMATE AIM OF THIS PROJECT TO CONTINUE BUILDING A CONSTITUENCY THAT CAN HAVE A DEEP APPRECIATION FOR AND DESIRE TO PROTECT CULTURAL AND PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES FOR THE PRESERVATION OF COLORADO S HISTORY
MT DAK PRESERVATION AND  CURATION OF FOSSIL VERTEBRATES FROM THE LATE CRETACEOUS HELL CREEK FORMATION

CROW CANYON WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH, DEVELOP AND PRESENT HERITAGE EDUCATION AND INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS, AND CREATE PARTNERSHIPS WITH AMERICAN INDIANS FOCUSED ON THE RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND INTERPRETATIVE OBJECTIVES OF BOTH ORGANIZATIONS  THE PROPOSED OBJECTIVES ALIGN WITH THE CROW CANYON ARCHAEOLOGICAL CENTER S  CCAC , VISION, MISSION, AND ON GOING RESEARCH PROJECTS AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS

THE   OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TWO FOLD  CREATE A HISTORIC CONTEXT FOR   RESOURCES IN THE  GREAT SAGE PLAN , AND TO BRING TOGETHER STAKEHOLDERS AND   RESEARCH TO ACCOMPLISH THIS TASK IN A COLLABORATIVE SPACE  THE HISTORIC   CONTEXT WILL BE WITHIN THE FORMAT OF THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES    NRHP S  MULTIPLE PROPERTY DOCUMENTATION FORM  MPDF , AS THAT REQUIRES   SPECIFIC DISCUSSIONS OF THEMES, INTEGRITY EXPECTATIONS, PROPERTY TYPES, AND   OVERALL ASSESSMENT RUBRIC FOR NRHP ELIGIBILITY  THE STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION   OFFICE, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, AND OTHER PARTNERS HAVE ALREADY DISCUSSED   THE NEED FOR THIS CONTEXT, AND THIS PROPOSAL IS MEANT TO COALESCE THESE   EFFORTS INTO A WRITTEN DOCUMENT USING INPUT FROM PRIVATE AND PUBLIC STAKEHOLDERS THE PROJECT GOALS WILL INCLUDE SYNTHESIS   OF KNOWN ARCHAEOLOGICAL DATA FOR THE PROJECT AREA  THIS WILL INCLUDE DIGITAL   CUTS FROMTHE SHPO AND BLM THAT COULD   INCLUDE GIS AND TABULAR DATA COORDINATE   AT LEAST TWO MEETINGS  IN PERSON AND HYBRID VIRTUAL  WITH KEY STAKEHOLDERS   INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE   SHPO, BLM, UNITED STATES FOREST SERVICE, NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBES, FRIENDS OF CEDAR MESA, EDGE   OF THE CEDARS STATE PARK, AND OTHERS INTERESTED RESEARCHERS AS DEFINED BY THE   SHPO AND BLMCONSULTANT   WILL COORDINATE WITH RESEARCHERS TO EITHER       A  HAVE EXTERNAL PARTIES PROVIDE TEXT FOR THE MPDF OR      B  PROVIDE ROBUST RESEARCH CITATIONS DATA FOR USE BY THE   CONSULTANT    4  CONSULTANT   WILL INTEGRATE DATA AND RESEARCH FROM ITEMS  1, 2, AND 3 INTO THE MPDF, AND COORDINATE REVIEWS       WITH ALL   INTERESTED PARTIES IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THIS PRODUCT    5  FINAL   PRODUCT WILL BE A FORMAL MPDF BUT WILL NOT BE PROVIDED TO THE NRHP FOR   ACCEPTANCE, BUT WILL REMAIN         FLEXIBLE TO BE ADDED EXPANDED IN THE FUTURE AS   NEW INFORMATION IS GIVEN  THIS FINAL PRODUCT IS HOPED TO BE        COMPLETED BY FALL   2025

THE   PROJECT PROPOSES TO LEVERAGE ALREADY DEVELOPED HIGHLY DETAILED DIGITAL   DOCUMENTATION OF MOON HOUSE IN BEARS EARS NATIONAL MONUMENT  BENM  TO BETTER   UNDERSTAND TRIBAL CONCERNS FOR AN IMPORTANT ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCE  THE PROJECT WILL USE ETHNOGRAPHIC, GEOSPATIAL, AND   PHOTOGRAMMETRIC METHODS, AND DRAW ON FEED BACK FROM   MIX OF TRIBAL CONSULTATIONS AND BROAD STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS, TO FURTHER   DEVELOP AND ENHANCE AN INTERACTIVE, IMMERSIVE VIRTUAL REALITY  VR  TOOL  THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE AN IMMERSIVE   VIRTUAL TOUR OF CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES WITHIN THE LANDSCAPE, AND ALSO   RAISE AWARENESS OF POTENTIALLY VISITOR IMPACTED PLACES AND RESOURCES  THIS   VIRTUAL TOUR WILL BE BASED ON INTERACTIVE 3D DIGITAL ENVIRONMENTS RENDERED IN   SIX DEGREES OF FREEDOM VR  THE EXPERIENCE WILL INTEGRATE INTERACTIVE CONTENT   INCLUDING 3D MODELS OF ARTIFACTS, VISUAL EXCAVATION DATA, HISTORICAL   PHOTOGRAPHS, AND AUDIO NARRATION, MADE AVAILABLE TO THE USER BY THEIR   PROXIMITY TO KEY POINTS IN THE VIRTUAL ENVIRONMENT, AND THEIR INTERACTION   WITH EMBEDDED OBJECTS THE   PROPOSED PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON SITES WITHIN THE CEDAR MESA REGION , THIS PROJECT   WILL DOCUMENT AND INTERPRET THE SITE KNOWN AS MOON HOUSE  SITE    42SA5005   M 1  AND THE ADJACENT MCLOYD CANYON DRAINAGE  IN CONSULTATION WITH BLM AND   OTHER STAKEHOLDERS, ADDITIONAL PHASES OF THE PROJECT COULD ALSO DOCUMENT   ADDITIONAL SITES WITHIN FISH CREEK CANYON PROJECT GOALS  IN KEEPING WITH THE PUBLIC AND PROGRAM INTERESTS OF   BLM, AND THE INTERESTS OF STAKEHOLDERS SPECIFICALLY IDENTIFIED IN THESE   GOALS, THE BROAD GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE AS FOLLOWS I  ENHANCED   UNDERSTANDING OF NATIVE AMERICAN AND ARCHAEOLOGICAL PERSPECTIVES ON CULTURAL   AND NATURAL RESOURCES,   AMONG THE VISITING PUBLIC AND AGENCY LAND MANAGERS II    DRAWING ON NATIVE AMERICAN   PERSPECTIVES FOR ENHANCED CULTURAL INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATIONAL TOOLS AND RESOURCES III    IMPROVED ACCESSIBILITY FOR VISITORS WITH DISABILITIES, INCLUDING NATIVE   AMERICANS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC, BY DEVELOPING VIRTUAL EXPERIENCES OF   PUBLIC LAND CULTURAL RESOURCES IV  FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADOPTION OF AGREED   APPROACHES, AMONG PARTICIPATING CULTURALLY AFFILIATED TRIBES, FOR   INTEGRATING NEW DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES AS PART OF BLM CULTURAL RESOURCE   DOCUMENTATION AND MANAGEMENT

THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE PRESERVATION WORK ON THE HISTORIC RAEL RANCH PROPERTY AND HOUSE WITH THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF OPENING THE PROPERTY UP TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC  WORK INCLUDES MAINTAINING TRADITIONAL LANDSCAPES, PRESERVING WATER RIGHTS BY RESTORING THE RAEL ACEQUIA, STABILIZING THE RAEL RANCH HOUSE AND ASSOCIATED STRUCTURES, AND EVENTUAL RESTORATION, BACK TO THE ORIGINAL DESIGN OF THE RAEL RANCH HOME  COORDINATION WITH BLM AND THE STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICER  SHPO  WILL OCCUR TO RESEARCH THE HOUSE AND THE ARCHITECTURAL CHANGES THAT HAVE OCCURRED OVER THE PAST 50 YEARS, INCLUDING THE DEVELOPMENT OF A FUTURE PLAN FOR POTENTIAL HOUSE INTERPRETATION OR EXHIBITS AND FINALIZING THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES REGISTRATION FORM CURRENTLY IN DRAFT FORM  ALSO INCLUDED IN THE AGREEMENT IS TO CONTINUE VOLUNTEER TRAINING IN TRADITIONAL SKILLS, PARTICULARLY ADOBE AND STONE MASONRY, IN ORDER TO CARRY OUT ACTUAL PERIOD APPROPRIATE RESTORATION WORK KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM RECIPIENT S RESEARCH ON THE STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY OF ASSETS AT THE RAEL PROPERTY WILL INFORM THE RECREATION MANAGEMENT PLAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT  DECISIONS ABOUT THE EXTENT OF FUTURE PUBLIC USE HINGE ON THE FEASIBILITY OF RESTORATION OF THE RAEL HOUSE WHICH WILL BE ASSESSED BY CORNERSTONES  SPECIALISTS  THE MANUAL FOR THE ACEQUIA WILL BE USED AS A GUIDE FOR LONG TERM MAINTENANCE OF THE DITCH, PRESERVING ACQUIRED BLM WATER RIGHTS AND SUPPORTING PLANNED SEED BANK PROJECTS  VOLUNTEER WORKSHOPS HELD REGULARLY WILL PROVIDE INSTRUCTION IN TRADITIONAL RESTORATION TECHNIQUES TO INTERESTED LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS  INTERN ARCHITECTS AND APPRENTICE ORCHARDISTS MAY ALSO BENEFIT FROM UNIQUE RESTORATION TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO INCREASE APPRECIATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE DEFENSIVE SITES OF DINETAHTHROUGH THE COMPLETION OF A 3D DIGITAL DOCUMENTATION AND ONLINE STORYTELLING PROJECT FEATURING NAVAJONARRATORS  CYARK IS SEEKING TO PARTNER WITH THE BLM FARMINGTON FIELD OFFICE AND MEMBERS OF THE NAVAJONATION TO DEVELOP A SET OF VIRTUAL INTERACTIVE EXPERIENCES OF THE CROW CANYON PUEBLITO AND THE MAIN PANELPETROGLYPHS FOUND IN THE CROW CANYON ARCHAEOLOGICAL DISTRICT  LOCATED APPROXIMATELY THIRTY MILES SOUTHEASTOF FARMINGTON, NEW MEXICO, THE CROW CANYON ARCHAEOLOGICAL DISTRICT IS FOUND WITHIN DINETAH, THE TRADITIONALHOMELAND OF THE NAVAJO  THE DISTRICT INCLUDES A NUMBER OF IMPORTANT PREHISTORIC SITES INCLUDING PUEBLOSTRUCTURES, GRANARIES, AND INCREDIBLE EXAMPLES OF ROCK ART DATING FROM THE 16 18TH CENTURIES  FEATURING SOMEOF THE BEST EXAMPLES OF NAVAJO PETROGLYPHS FROM THIS PERIOD IN THE SOUTHWEST, THIS SITE REMAINS INCREDIBLYIMPORTANT TO NATIVE AMERICAN PEOPLES TODAY PROVIDING A CONNECTION TO THE PAST AND SHEDDING LIGHT ON THISIMPORTANT PERIOD OF HISTORY  WORKING WITH THE FARMINGTON FIELD OFFICE AND DESCENDANT COMMUNITIES, CYAKWILL DIGITALLY DOCUMENT THE CROW CANYON PUEBLITO AND THE MAIN PANEL PETROGLYPHS WHICH WILL RESULT INPHOTO REALISTIC 3D MODELS WHICH WILL BE USED AS THE FOUNDATION FOR TWO VIRTUAL EXPERIENCES  THE ONLINEEXPERIENCES WILL BE PUBLISHED IN BOTH ENGLISH AND NAVAJO AND WILL BE NARRATED BY MEMBERS OF THE NAVAJONATION IDENTIFIED BY THE BLM FARMINGTON OFFICE  THE VIRTUAL EXPERIENCES WILL RESULT IN COMPELLING ONLINERESOURCES THAT WILL BE USED FOR EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH PURPOSES WHILE THE UNDERLYING 3D DATA WILL ALSOADVANCE THE ABILITY OF THE BLM TO MANAGE THESE RESOURCES IN THE FUTURE

THE PALEONTOLOGY SECTION AT THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY  UCM  IS REQUESTING FUNDING AND COLLABORATION FROM THE BLM NEW MEXICO STATE OFFICE TO CLEAN UP, CONFIRM LAND OWNERSHIP, DIGITIZE, GEOREFERENCE, AND MAP IN GIS 618 LEGACY PALEONTOLOGICAL LOCALITIES THAT FALL UNDER THE JURISDICTION OF THE REGIONAL PALEONTOLOGIST AT THE BLM NEW MEXICO STATE OFFICE  THE SPECIMENS FROM THESE LOCALITIES ARE HOUSED IN THE UCM PALEONTOLOGY COLLECTIONS  ONCE COMPLETED, THE UCM LOCALITY DATA WILL BE SHARED WITH THE CENTRALIZED PALEONTOLOGY LOCALITY DATABASE AT THE BLM NEW MEXICO STATE OFFICE, ENSURING THAT THE BLM HAS THE MOST CURRENT DATA WITH WHICH TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ON THE CARE, MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES  ACTIVITIES ON THIS PROJECT WILL BE LARGELY COMPLETED BY AT LEAST THREE STUDENTS AT CU BOULDER WHO WILL BE SUPERVISED AND MENTORED BY UCM CURATORS EBERLE AND SIMPSON AND PALEONTOLOGY COLLECTIONS MANAGERS KARIM, AND VAN VELDHUIZEN THIS PROJECT WILL FURTHER DOI PRIORITIES AS WELL AS HELP INFORM BLM MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AND GOALS IN THE FOLLOWING WAYS  FIRST, THE PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY FOSSIL LOCALITIES ON  AND NEAR  BLM LANDS THAT ARE AT RISK OF DAMAGE FROM ACCELERATED EROSION DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE SO THAT THEY CAN BE APPROPRIATELY MONITORED FOR PROTECTION  SECOND, THE PROJECT WILL ASSIST WITH PALEONTOLOGICAL DATA AND RECORDS MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES SUCH AS CREATING, DIGITIZING, AND MAINTAINING GEOSPATIAL DATA THAT WILL BE SHARED WITH THE BLM NEW MEXICO STATE OFFICE  THIRD, THE PROJECT WILL HELP SUPPORT THE BLM S RESPONSIBLE DEVELOPMENT OF RENEWABLE ENERGY ON PUBLIC LANDS AND WATERS BY IDENTIFYING PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES THAT MAY BE WITHIN AREAS OF RENEWABLE ENERGY PROJECTS FOURTH, WE WILL TRAIN FUTURE CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTITIONERS AND PALEONTOLOGISTS  TRAINING AND PARTICIPATION IN ALL ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT ENSURES THAT AT LEAST THREE STUDENTS  AND PROBABLY MORE  AT CU BOULDER WILL GAIN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING IN DIGITIZING, GEOREFERENCING AND MAPPING OF FOSSIL LOCALITIES, AND THEY WILL LEARN WHY IT IS SO IMPORTANT TO CAPTURE ACCURATE LOCALITY DATA IN THE FIELD  GEOREFERENCING SKILLS AND EXPERIENCE ARE INCREASINGLY REQUIRED FOR GRADUATES TO GAIN EMPLOYMENT AS COLLECTIONS MANAGERS AND PALEONTOLOGISTS IN MUSEUMS AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS THAT HOUSE AND MANAGE PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES AS WELL AS WORKING FOR MITIGATION COMPANIES AS WELL AS STATE AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, INCLUDING THE BLM  LASTLY, OUR PROJECT WILL PROMOTE PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT, LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES, AND PALEONTOLOGICAL ETHICS THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS AND EVENTS  WE ALSO PLAN TO PRESENT OUR PROTOCOL FOR DIGITIZING AND GEOREFERENCING THE UCM LOCALITIES AT PROFESSIONAL MEETINGS  E G , GSA, SVP  WITH REGARD TO EXPECTED OUTCOMES, WE WILL DIGITIZE, GEOREFERENCE, MAP, AND CONFIRM THE LAND OWNERSHIP FOR 618 OF THE MUSEUM S LEGACY LOCALITIES WHOSE SPECIMENS ARE HOUSED IN THE UCM PALEONTOLOGY COLLECTIONS AND WHICH FALL UNDER JURISDICTION OF THE BLM REGIONAL PALEONTOLOGIST AT THE NEW MEXICO STATE OFFICE  THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE THE MOST ACCURATE AND CURRENT LOCALITY INFORMATION THAT WILL THEN BE SHARED WITH THE BLM NEW MEXICO STATE OFFICE AND SUBSEQUENTLY THE RESPECTIVE FIELD OFFICES, RESEARCHERS, AND CLIENTS SERVED BY THEM  ACCURATE AND PRECISE LOCALITY INFORMATION WILL BETTER PREPARE THE BLM TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ON THE LOCATIONS OF PIPELINES, WELL PADS, RENEWABLE ENERGY PROJECTS, AND OTHER DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS THAT COULD IMPACT PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES ON BLM LAND  THE ACCURATE IDENTIFICATION OF ALL PALEONTOLOGY LOCALITIES FURTHER BENEFITS THE PUBLIC IN THAT IT WILL FACILITATE THE IDENTIFICATION OF THOSE LOCALITIES THAT HAVE THE POTENTIAL VALUE AND DEVELOPMENT FOR PUBLIC INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION

THIS PROPOSAL SUMMARIZES THE WASHINGTON STATE   UNIVERSITY  WSU  MUSEUM OF ANTHROPOLOGY  MUSEUM  PLAN TO CONDUCT ONGOING   CURATION AND STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL MATERIALS, UNDER A   FIVE YEAR COLLABORATIVE ECOSYSTEM UNIT  CESU  AGREEMENT BETWEEN WSU AND THE   WA OR BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM   THE PROJECT IS FUNDAMENTALLY RELATED   TO CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AS CURATION SUPPORT IS ESSENTIAL TO ENSURING   BLM COLLECTIONS ARE SAFELY HOUSED, PROFESSIONALLY CURATED, AND AVAILABLE TO   THE PUBLIC AND RESEARCHERS THE PROJECT INVOLVES CURATION SERVICES AND ACTIVITIES BY THE WSU MUSEUM IN ACCORDANCE WITH 36 CFR PART 79, INCLUDING PROVIDING SAFE AND SECURE HOUSING FOR SPOKANE BLM COLLECTIONS, MAINTAINING, AND PROVIDING FOR THE PROFESSIONAL CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF THE COLLECTIONS, AND FACILITATING ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS BY QUALIFIED USERS FOR SCIENTIFIC, EDUCATIONAL, AND RELIGIOUS PURPOSES

THE   OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT AN INSTRUMENTAL NEUTRON ACTIVATION   ANALYSIS  INAA  WITH THE GOAL OF RECONSTRUCTING POTENTIALLY EXTENSIVE   PREHISTORIC CERAMIC TRADE NETWORKS AMONG THE THREE JORNADA MOGOLLON CULTURE   SUBREGIONS   THE NORTHERN, SOUTHERN AND EASTERN JORNADA AREAS IN   THE AMERICAN SOUTHWEST, MUCH RESEARCH WITH A FOCUS ON SOCIAL INTERACTION   AMONG THE NEIGHBORING PREHISTORIC PUEBLOS HAS BEEN UNDERTAKEN  WHILE THESE   STUDIES HAVE ADVANCED OUR UNDERSTANDING OF STRONG ECONOMIC TIES BETWEEN THE   NEIGHBORING REGIONS, THEY HAVE ONLY PROVIDED INDICATIONS OF CASUAL EXCHANGE   OF GOODS  IN SOME CASES, POTENTIAL EVIDENCE FOR GREATER EXCHANGE OF GOODS HAS   BEEN OBSERVED AMONG PUEBLOS OF A SINGLE CULTURAL REGION  YET, SUCH DATA ARE   CURRENTLY MISSING TO SUPPORT INFERENCES ABOUT THE EXISTENCE OF   WELL STRUCTURED TRADE NETWORKS BETWEEN NEIGHBORING CULTURAL REGIONS  THESE   GAPS IN PREHISTORIC PUEBLO EXCHANGE OF GOODS CAST A SHADOW ABOUT   ARCHAEOLOGISTS  BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE STRUCTURE OF ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL   TIES BETWEEN PUEBLOS FROM DISTANT CULTURAL REGIONS  THIS IS TRUE IN   PARTICULAR ABOUT THE JORNADA MOGOLLON CULTURAL SUBREGIONS WHERE THE KNOWLEDGE   OF LARGE SCALE TRADING OF COMMODITIES, SUCH AS CERAMICS, IS LARGELY LACKING EXPECTED DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE 40 COPIES OF A FORMAL, PERFECT BOUND REPORT DETAILING THE STUDY RESULTS AND 600 COPIES OF A FOLDABLE BROCHURE INTENDED FOR FREE PUBLIC DISSEMINATION OF THE RESEARCH RESULTS  THESE BROCHURES WILL BE AVAILABLE AT THE BLM AND LINCOLN NATIONAL FOREST OFFICES, AS WELL AS AT WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE  INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM THE IN FIELD RECORDED PUEBLOS, SUCH AS SITE MAPS, FEATURE PHOTOGRAPHS AND SITE FEATURE DESCRIPTIONS, WILL BE UPLOADED TO THE BLM AND LINCOLN NF WEBSITES TO BE VIEWED FOR FREE BY THE PUBLIC  FURTHERMORE, AERIAL VIDEOS AND PHOTOGRAPHS MADE USING A DRONE SURVEY OF THE THREE SITES ON THE LINCOLN NF WILL BE UPLOADED TO THE WEBSITESTHERE ARE MULTIPLE EXPECTED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS   STUDY  FIRST, THIS RESEARCH HAS THE POTENTIAL TO DEMONSTRATE TRADE NETWORKS   BETWEEN THE EASTERN JORNADA SITES OF THE PERMIAN BASIN PROGRAMMATIC AGREEMENT   AREA AND THE NEIGHBORING NORTHERN AND SOUTHERN JORNADA PUEBLOS  SECOND, IT   WILL INFORM THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND THE TRIBAL NATIONS ABOUT THE   POTENTIALLY EXTENSIVE JORNADA MOGOLLON TRADE NETWORKS  THIRD, THE RESEARCH   FINDINGS WILL BE MADE PUBLIC THROUGH THE PRODUCTION OF A BROCHURE AS WELL AS   THE SITE FIELD MAPS AND PHOTOGRAPHS THIS PROJECT WILL FURTHER THE BIDEN HARRIS ADMINISTRATION S GOAL OF ADVANCING RACIAL EQUITY AND SUPPORT FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT BY CONTINUED COLLABORATION WITH TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICERS  THPOS   THE RESULTS OF THE STUDY WILL IDENTIFY ARCHEOLOGICAL SITES MEETING THE CRITERIA FOR LISTING ON THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES

HELP PROTECT AND PRESERVE CULTURAL RESOURCES FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS AND FACILITATE SUBSTANTIAL TRAINING, RESEARCH, AND CAREER BUILDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE NEXT GENERATION OF ARCHAEOLOGISTS AND HERITAGE MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONALS  THE FIELD SCHOOL IS EXPLICITLY DESIGNED WITH INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES TO PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH THE SKILLS THAT ARE NECESSARY TO ENGAGE IN TRIBAL CONSULTATION AND COLLABORATION IN A MANNER THAT IS ETHICAL, RECIPROCAL, AND SUSTAINABLE

THE PRIMARY DELIVERABLE FOR THIS PROJECT IS A WEBSITE THAT SUPPORTS INTERPRETIVE AND EDUCATIONAL INFORMATION ON SOUTHERN NEW MEXICO ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES  THE WEBSITE INCORPORATES DIGITIZED COLLECTIONS AND OTHER MATERIALS FROM THE PERMIAN BASIN AREA, ALLOWING VISITORS TO EXPLORE THE CULTURAL HERITAGE AND LONG HISTORY OF DIFFERENT PEOPLES  RELATIONSHIPS TO THE VARIOUS LANDS OF SOUTHERN NEW MEXICO AS WELL AS LEARN ABOUT CONTEMPORARY ARCHAEOLOGICAL ETHICS AND SCIENTIFIC DEVELOPMENTS  FUNDING WILL BE USED PRIMARILY TO SUPPORT ADVISORY COMMITTEE MEMBERS, STUDENT INTERNS, AND OTHER PERSONNEL WHO WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DIGITIZING, ORGANIZING, MAINTAINING MATERIALS FOR WEBSITE CONTENT  WEBSITE DEVELOPMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE  AND OUTREACH TO AUDIENCES IDENTIFIED BY THE ADVISORY COMMITTEE, TO INCLUDE ENTHUSIASTS, STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND INDEPENDENT RESEARCHERS OR RECREATIONAL PUBLIC LANDS USERS  IT WILL ALSO SUPPORT WORK BY PARTNERS THAT OFFER DIFFERENT PERSPECTIVES ON THE SAME TOPICS, WITH A FOCUS ON STUDENT ENGAGEMENT THIS PROJECT WILL FURTHER THE BIDEN HARRIS ADMINISTRATION S GOAL OF ADVANCING RACIAL EQUITY AND SUPPORT FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT THROUGH CONTINUED COLLABORATION WITH TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICERS  THPOS  TO INCLUDE MATERIALS ON THE WEBSITE THAT WILL ENGAGE YOUTH, PROFESSIONALS, AND ENTHUSIASTS, PARTICULARLY IN TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, WITH IN PERSON PROGRAMS AND BORN DIGITAL RESOURCES THAT ENCOURAGE APPRECIATION FOR THE SCIENCE AND PRACTICE OF ARCHAEOLOGY GENERALLY AND SPECIFICALLY REGARDING THE CULTURAL RESOURCES OF SOUTHERN NEW MEXICO  THE COLLABORATION WITH ISLETA PUEBLO AND THE MESCALERO APACHE ALSO MEETS THE DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR S PRIORITY OF STRENGTHENING THE GOVERNMENT TO GOVERNMENT RELATIONSHIP WITH SOVEREIGN TRIBAL NATIONS THROUGH MAKING DIGITIZED ARTIFACTS AND COLLECTIONS ACCESSIBLE ONLINE TO NATIVE AMERICANS AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC, THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT BLM MANAGEMENT ACTIONS THAT INCLUDE PROTECTING AND PRESERVING CULTURAL HERITAGE AND PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES FOR THE BENEFIT OF FUTURE GENERATIONS, IMPROVING PROFESSIONAL AND PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE NATION S CULTURAL HISTORY, AND PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC  DIGITIZING ARTIFACTS AND COLLECTIONS TO BE SHARED ON THE WEBSITEPROVIDES EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENT INTERNS IN MANAGING HERITAGE RESOURCE COLLECTIONS AND THEIRASSOCIATED RECORDS THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT IS A WEBSITE THAT WILL SERVE AS A UNIQUE RESOURCE THATPROVOKES CURIOSITY AROUND THE CULTURAL HERITAGE AND HISTORY OF SOUTHERN NEW MEXICO AS WELL ASCONTEMPORARY ARCHAEOLOGICAL PRACTICES  WHILE THERE HAS BEEN A GREAT DEAL OF FASCINATING SCIENTIFICRESEARCH ON THE ARCHAEOLOGY OF SOUTHERN NEW MEXICO, THERE IS VERY LITTLE GENERAL KNOWLEDGE OF THESE SITES,THESE CULTURES, OR EVEN OF THE LONG RECORD OF HUMAN OCCUPATION  THANKS TO THE INPUT FROM THE ADVISORYCOMMITTEE, THE SITE WILL SUPPORT SPATIAL VISUALIZATIONS AROUND THE LAND TYPES, SO E G  VISITORS CAN SEE HOWUSE SHIFTED IN THE PECOS RIVER VALLEY OR ON THE SLOPES OF THE SACRAMENTO MOUNTAINS OVER TIME, AS WELL ASINDICATIONS OF TRADE, CLIMATE SHIFTS, AND MIGRATION  ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT AWARENESS OF THE WEBSITE ANDDIRECTLY ENGAGE THE PUBLIC, ESPECIALLY YOUTH, ARE DESIGNED TO INSPIRE A SENSE OF STEWARDSHIP IN FUTURE GENERATIONS

THE SOUTHWESTERN OREGON  SWO  INDIGENOUS GARDENS   NETWORK  IGN  WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF SILETZ   INDIANS  CTSI  AND THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF GRAND RONDE  CTGR , AND NATIVE   COMMUNITIES SEEKING TO BUILD SUSTAINABLE FOOD SYSTEMS THAT IMPROVE WELLBEING,   STRENGTHEN FOOD SECURITY, AND INCREASE THEIR RELATIONSHIP WITH FIRST FOOD,   MEDICINE, AND FIBER PLANTS AND FOOD NETWORKS  INCREASING ACCESS TO FIRST FOODS AND FIRST FOOD   LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR IGN TRIBAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL BE ACHIEVED   THROUGH THE ORGANIZATION OF THREE TO FIVE SEASONAL FIRST FOOD GATHERINGS   EVENTS OVER THE THREE YEAR PROJECT PERIOD  THESE MAY INCLUDE AN EVENT FOCUSING   ON SUMMER FOOD PLANT SPECIES  CAMASSIA SPP  , AND ONE FOCUSING ON FALL FOOD   RESOURCES  QUERCUS SPP    ADDITIONAL SPECIES OF INTEREST   INCLUDE  MADIA SPP , PERIDERIDIA SPP , AND ANGELICA SPP   MAY BE INCLUDED IN   FIRST FOOD GATHERING ACTIVITIES

PLANTS THAT STORE STARCH IN UNDERGROUND ORGANS  GEOPHYTES  ARE HIGHLY VALUED AS FOOD AND THEIR AVAILABILITY AND USE HAVE IMPLICATIONS ACROSS THE GLOBE  IN THE FORT ROCK BASIN OF SOUTHERN OREGON SPECIFICALLY, GEOPHYTE COLLECTING BY INDIGENOUS PEOPLE WAS PART OF A SEASONAL ACTIVITY THAT INCLUDED SOCIALIZING, TRADING, AND GAMING  THE EXTENT OF GEOPHYTE USE  ACROSS TIME AND SPACE , HOWEVER, HAS NOT YET BEEN INVESTIGATED  THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT  L20AS00005  APPLIED A NOVEL METHOD TO EXTRACT PLANT STARCH FROM BEDROCK GRINDING SURFACES AND FOUND THAT GEOPHYTES  SPECIFICALLY THE PLANT KNOWN AS BISCUITROOT OR LOMATIUM SPP   WERE COLLECTED AND PROCESSED IN UPLAND CAMPS AS EARLY AS 12,000 YEARS AGO  IT IS STILL UNCLEAR, HOWEVER, WHETHER SUCH PLANTS WERE ESSENTIAL TO HUMAN DIETS THROUGHOUT PREHISTORY  CLARIFICATION OF THE EXTENT OF GEOPHYTE USE BY EXAMINING GROUND STONE TOOLS FROM 1  MULTIPLE SITES IN THE FORT ROCK BASIN, 2  TIME PERIODS THAT SPAN THE ENTIRE 12,000 YEARS OF PREHISTORY, AND 3  BOTH UPLAND AND LOWLAND ENVIRONMENTS IS NECESSARY  IT IS PLANNED TO SAMPLE 75 GROUND STONE TOOLS FOR PLANT STARCH  AND ASSOCIATED SEDIMENTS AS A  CONTROL   FROM ARCHAEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS HELD AT UNIVERSITY OF OREGON NATURAL AND CULTURAL HISTORY MUSEUM  DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT INCLUDING ALL PROJECT DATA AND A SCHOLARLY PUBLICATION FOR PUBLIC DISSEMINATION  CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS WILL ALSO BE MADE

THE SITE STEWARD PROGRAM PROVIDES SIGNIFICANT ASSISTANCE TO FEDERAL, STATE AND MUNICIPAL LAND MANAGERS WITH ONE SITE STEWARD COORDINATOR OVERSEEING 25 REGIONS AND MORE THAN 700 VOLUNTEERS MONITORING THE CONDITION OF OVER 1600 ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES THROUGHOUT ARIZONA.

FOR EACH PROJECT HISTORICORPS WILL: - PROVIDE PROJECT DEVELOPMENT AND MANAGEMENT TO DETERMINE AN APPROPRIATE SCOPE OF  WORK, PROJECT BUDGET, ESTABLISH THE NUMBER OF WORK SESSIONS (5-DAY WORK PERIODS), AND  RECRUIT VOLUNTEERS NEEDED TO ACCOMPLISH SAID SCOPE;  - PROVIDE AT LEAST 2 FIELD STAFF (ONE PROJECT SUPERVISOR AND ONE CREW LEADER) TO INSTRUCT,  COACH, AND INSPIRE UNSKILLED AND SEMI-SKILLED VOLUNTEERS IN A SAFE, INCLUSIVE, AND  SUPPORTIVE LEARNING ENVIRONMENT; - PROVIDE THE NECESSARY TOOLS, EQUIPMENT (INCLUDING PPE), AND TRAINING TO SAFELY EXECUTE  THE SCOPE OF WORK AND ENSURE A MEANINGFUL VOLUNTEER LEARNING EXPERIENCE; - ENSURE THAT WORK COMPLIES WITH THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR'S STANDARDS FOR TREATMENT  OF HISTORIC PROPERTIES AND GUIDELINES FOR PRESERVING, REHABILITATING, RESTORING, AND  RECONSTRUCTING HISTORIC BUILDINGS (SOIS) (36 CFR PART 68); AND THAT WORK COMPLETED IS  DOCUMENTED AT THE END OF THE PROJECT VIA A PERFORMANCE REPORT SUBMITTED TO THE  PROJECT PARTNER.

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO INCREASE APPRECIATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE SHIRK RANCH HISTORIC DISTRICT THROUGH THE COMPLETION OF A 3D DOCUMENTATION STORYTELLING PROJECT. AS ONE OF THE MOST INTACT RANCH COMPLEXES DATING FROM THE LATE 1800S, THIS EXPERIENCE WILL HELP SHED LIGHT ON LATE NINETEENTH AND EARLY TWENTIETH-CENTURY FREE-RANGE RANCHING PRACTICES AND PROVIDE A PRIMER FOR UNDERSTANDING THE HISTORY OF LAKE COUNTY. CYARK STAFF WILL TRAVEL TO THE SITE TO COMPLETE LIDAR LASER SCANNING AND DIGITAL PHOTOGRAMMETRY OF THE IDENTIFIED HISTORIC STRUCTURES TO PROVIDE THE BLM WITH HIGH-RESOLUTION DIGITAL ASSETS THAT CAN BE USED TO IMPROVE THE EXISTING INTERPRETATION OF THE SITE. WHILE ON-SITE, CYARK WILL RECORD INTERVIEWS WITH STAFF MEMBERS FROM THE LAKEVIEW FIELD OFFICE AS WELL AS COMMUNITY MEMBERS IDENTIFIED BY THE BLM. FOLLOWING THE FIELD EXPEDITION, CYARK STAFF WILL PROCESS THE RESULTING 3D DATA AND COLLECTED INTERVIEWS TO PRODUCE A MOBILE-RESPONSIVE WEB EXPERIENCE THAT WILL BE MADE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC VIA CYARK.ORG. CYARK WILL WORK WITH THE BLM AND THE LOCAL COMMUNITY TO ANNOTATE THE EXPERIENCE WITH SUPPLEMENTAL MULTIMEDIA, INCLUDING HISTORIC IMAGERY, TO SHARE THE MANY STORIES OF THIS SITE WITH THE PUBLIC. THE RESULTING MATERIALS FROM THIS COLLABORATION WILL NOT ONLY BE USED FOR EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH PURPOSES BUT WILL ALSO ADVANCE THE ABILITY OF THE BLM TO MANAGE THESE RESOURCES IN THE FUTURE AND WILL PROVIDE AN ACCURATE POINT-IN-TIME ASSESSMENT OF EACH RESOURCE.

THE LINCOLN COUNTY ARCHAEOLOGICAL INITIATIVE (LCAI) PROGRAM IMPLEMENTS PROJECTS THAT INCLUDE ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCE IDENTIFICATION, DATA COLLECTION, INVENTORIES, EXISTING RECORD ENHANCEMENT, AND DATA ANALYSIS USING INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGY AND TECHNIQUES. PUBLIC OUTREACH EFFORTS WILL EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ON THE IMPORTANCE OF PRESERVING ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCES IN LINCOLN COUNTY.

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE EXCAVATION OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES IN STRATA BELOW AND ABOVE THE TEPHRA DEPOSITED DURING THE MOUNT CHURCHILL (WHITE RIVER ASH DEPOSIT) BETWEEN 1,900 AND 1,200 YEARS AGO IN ORDER TO TEST THE HYPOTHESIS THAT THE MOUNT CHURCHILL ERUPTION MAY HAVE PROVIDED THE CATALYST FOR THE DISPERSION/MIGRATION OF ATHABASKAN, OR DENE, SPEAKERS FROM THE SUBARCTIC, ULTIMATELY LEADING TO AMERICAN SOUTHWEST (NAVAJO AND APACHE). PHASE I: FIELD RESEARCH AT KNOWN CULTURAL SITES EITHER ABOVE OR BELOW THE WHITE RIVER ASH DEPOSIT. PHASE II: LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF LITHIC AND FAUNAL SAMPLES COLLECTED DURING PHASE I AND FURTHER ANALYSIS OF EXTANT ASSEMBLAGES INCLUDING RADIOCARBON DATING.
